newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: U.N. official calls for more food aid to N.Korea.
newsitem.headline: U.N. official calls for more food aid to N.Korea.

text.p: A top United Nations official said on Saturday that North Korea's food crisis was serious and called for more international food aid.
"I was able to assess the extent of the food crisis in the North as very serious and prevailing," U.N. Undersecretary General Yasushi Akashi told a press conference.
Akashi paid a four-day visit to North Korea, which has been hit by famine following poor harvests due to massive flooding in 1995 and 1996.
Although foreign had helped alleviate the crisis, North Korea still had a shortage of between 700,000 and 800,000 tonnes of food, Akashi said.

He dismissed arguments that Pyongyang was relying on outside food aid and making no efforts of its own to tackle the crisis, saying: "I have the distinct impression that they are making their own efforts, they are very proud people."
"They were trying to be self-reliant, but they cannot," he said, adding that a shortage of fertilisers and insecticides was hampering their efforts.
The UN aims to collect $126 million worth of food aid during the year to March 1998, and around 40 percent of the target had already been reached, Akashi said.
The United States has pledged $25 million and South Korea $16 million in response to the UN's appeal for aid.
On Friday, North Korea's official Korean Central News Agency quoted Akashi as saying 60 to 65 percent of children in flood-hit areas were suffering from malnutrition.
Akashi was the first high-ranking U.N. official to visit North Korea to investigate the food crisis since mid-March, when a mission was sent by the World Food Programme.
He is scheduled to meet South Korea government officials in Seoul before travelling to Tokyo on Monday.
